translated_dialog: If music feeds love and makes it stronger, then keep playing music. Give me too much of it, so much that it kills my longing for love and makes it go away. Play that part againit sounded melancholy. Oh, it sounded to me like a sweet breeze blowing over a bank of violets, stealing their scent and distributing it to everyone. That's enough now, no more music. It doesn't sound as sweet as it did before. Oh spirit of love, how restless you are! You make me want to accept everything, like the sea does, but then the next minute everything seems worthless, no matter how valuable it is. Love is like a hallucinationnothing else is so imaginative and extravagant.
og_response: Will you go hunt, my lord?

translated_dialog: Do you want to go hunting, my lord?
og_response: What, Curio?

translated_dialog: Hunting what, Curio?
og_response: The hart.

translated_dialog: The hart.
og_response: Why, so I do, the noblest that I have.    Oh, when mine eyes did see Olivia first,    Methought she purged the air of pestilence.    That instant was I turned into a hart,    And my desires, like fell and cruel hounds,    E'er since pursue me.

translated_dialog: I am already hunting a hart, but it's also my heart being hunted. Oh, when I first saw Olivia, it seemed to me that she purified the air with her very presence. In that instant I was transformed into a hart, and ever since then my desire for her has pursued me like a pack of cruel hunting hounds.
og_response: How now! What news from her?

translated_dialog: What's going on? What's the news from her?
og_response: So please my lord, I might not be admitted,    But from her handmaid do return this answer:    The element itself, till seven years' heat,    Shall not behold her face at ample view,    But like a cloistress, she will veiled walk    And water once a day her chamber round    With eye-offending brine   all this to season    A brothers dead love, which she would keep fresh    And lasting in her sad remembrance.

translated_dialog: I'm sorry, my lord, they wouldn't let me enter, but Olivia's handmaid gave me this answer: the outside world won't see Olivia's face for the next seven years. She'll wear a veil like a nun, and once a day she'll water her room with her tears. All of this is to preserve her love for her dead brother, whose memory she wants to keep fresh forever.
og_response: O, she that hath a heart of that fine frame    To pay this debt of love but to a brother,    How will she love, when the rich golden shaft    Hath killed the flock of all affections else    That live in her, when liver, brain, and heart,    These sovereign thrones, are all supplied, and filled    Her sweet perfections with one self king!    Away before me to sweet beds of flowers.    Love thoughts lie rich when canopied with bowers.

translated_dialog: What country is this, friends?
og_response: This is Illyria, lady.

translated_dialog: This is Illyria, my lady.
og_response: And what should I do in Illyria?    My brother he is in Elysium.    Perchance he is not drownd.What think you, sailors?

translated_dialog: And what should I do in Illyria? My brother is in Heaven. Or perhaps there's a chance he didn't drown. What do you think, sailors?
og_response: It is perchance that you yourself were saved.

translated_dialog: It was only by chance that you yourself were saved.
og_response: O, my poor brother! And so perchance may he be.

translated_dialog: Oh, my poor brother! But maybe he has been saved by chance too.
og_response: True, madam. And, to comfort you with chance,    Assure yourself, after our ship did split,    When you and those poor number saved with you    Hung on our driving boat,   I saw your brother,    Most provident in peril, bind himself,    Courage and hope both teaching him the practice,    To a strong mast that lived upon the sea,    Where, like Arion on the dolphins back,    I saw him hold acquaintance with the waves    So long as I could see.

translated_dialog: True, madam. And let me comfort you: when our ship was wrecked, and you and the few other survivors hung onto our drifting lifeboat, I saw your brother tie himself to the mast that was floating on the wavesacting with courage and hope in the middle of great danger. For as long as I could see him, he safely rode upon the waves like Arion on the dolphin's back.
og_response: [giving him money]    For saying so, theres gold.    Mine own escape unfoldeth to my hope,    Whereto thy speech serves for authority,    The like of him.   Knowst thou this country?

translated_dialog: [Giving him money] Here's some gold to thank you for telling me this. My own escape gives me hope for my brother, and what you've told me now gives me even more reason to hope. Do you know this country?
og_response: Ay, madam, well, for I was bred and bornNot three hours' travel from this very place.

translated_dialog: Yes, madam, I was born and raised less than three hours' travel from here.
og_response: Who governs here?

translated_dialog: Who rules here?
og_response: A noble duke, in natureAs in name.

translated_dialog: A duke who is as noble in his character as he is in his rank.
og_response: What is his name?

translated_dialog: What is his name?
og_response: Orsino.

translated_dialog: Orsino.
og_response: Orsino. I have heard my father name him. He was a bachelor then.

translated_dialog: OrsinoI have heard my father mention him. He was a bachelor back then.
og_response: And so is now, or was so very late.    For but a month ago I went from hence,    And then twas fresh in murmur   as, you know,    What great ones do the less will prattle of    That he did seek the love of fair Olivia.

translated_dialog: And he still is, or was very recently at least. I only left here a month ago, and at that time there was a popular rumoras, you know, people gossip about the nobilitythat he was courting the fair Olivia.
og_response: Whats she?

translated_dialog: Who's she?
og_response: A virtuous maid, the daughter of a count    That died some twelvemonth since,   then leaving her    In the protection of his son, her brother,    Who shortly also died,   for whose dear love,    They say, she hath abjured the company    And sight of men.

translated_dialog: A virtuous young woman, the daughter of a count who died a year ago. He left her in the care of his son, Olivia's brother, but the brother died soon after. They say that out of love for her brother, Olivia has stopped interacting with men altogether.
og_response: Oh, that I served that lady    And might not be delivered to the world,    Till I had made mine own occasion mellow,    What my estate is.

translated_dialog: Oh, I wish that I could serve that ladythen I wouldn't have to reveal myself to the world until I was ready to identify my place in society.
og_response: That were hard to compass,Because she will admit no kind of suit,No, not the dukes.

translated_dialog: That would be hard to bring about, because she won't allow anyone in to see her, not even the duke's men.
og_response: There is a fair behavior in thee, captain,    And though that nature with a beauteous wall    Doth oft close in pollution, yet of thee    I will believe thou hast a mind that suits    With this thy fair and outward character.    I pritheeand Ill pay thee bounteously    Conceal me what I am, and be my aid    For such disguise as haply shall become    The form of my intent   . Ill serve this duke.    Thou shall present me as an eunuch to him.    It may be worth thy pains, for I can sing    And speak to him in many sorts of music    That will allow me very worth his service.    What else may hap to time I will commit.    Only shape thou thy silence to my wit.

translated_dialog: You seem to be a good man in both behavior and appearance, captain, and even though nature often makes beautiful people corrupt on the inside, I believe that you have a noble mind to fit your good looks and manners. Pleaseand I'll pay you well for thishelp me conceal my identity, and find me the disguise that will suit my intentions. I want to serve this duke. You will present me to him as a eunuch. It will be worth your trouble, for I can sing and speak well, and he will surely consider me for his service. What might happen after that, only time will tell. You must only match my wit with your silence and discretion.
og_response: Be you his eunuch, and your mute Ill be.When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not see.

translated_dialog: You will be his eunuch, and I will be your mute attendant. If I tell your secret, may I lose my sight.
og_response: I thank thee. Lead me on.

translated_dialog: What is ailing my niece, that she reacts so strongly to her brother's death? I'm now sure that caring too much is bad for one's health.
og_response: By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o' nights. Your cousin, my lady, takes great exceptions to your ill hours.

translated_dialog: By God, Sir Toby, you must come home earlier at night. Your niece, my lady, strongly disapproves of the late hours you keep.
og_response: Why, let her except, before excepted.

translated_dialog: Well, let her disapprove of meI disapprove of her.
og_response: Ay, but you must confine yourself within the modest limits of order.

translated_dialog: Yes, but you must at least confine yourself within the limits of order and decency.
og_response: Confine? Ill confine myself no finer than I am.   These clothes are good enough to drink in, and so be these boots too.   An they be not, let them hang themselves in their own straps.

translated_dialog: Confine myself? I'll only confine myself to these clothes I'm wearing. They're good enough to drink in, and these boots are too. And if they aren't, then let them hang themselves by their own straps.
og_response: That quaffing and drinking will undo you:   I heard my lady talk of it yesterday, and of a foolish knight that you brought in one night here to be her wooer.

translated_dialog: All this drinking will be your ruin: I heard my lady Olivia talking about it yesterday. She also spoke of some foolish knight you brought here one night to woo her.
og_response: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

translated_dialog: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?
og_response: Ay, he.

translated_dialog: Yes, him.
og_response: Hes as tall a man as anys in Illyria.

translated_dialog: He's as tall and brave as any man in Illyria.
og_response: Whats that to the purpose?

translated_dialog: What does that have to do with anything?
og_response: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.

translated_dialog: Well, he has an income of three thousand ducats a year.
og_response: Ay, but hell have but a year in all these ducats. Hesa very fool and a prodigal.

translated_dialog: Yes, but he'll only make all those ducats last for one year. He's foolish, wasteful, and reckless.
og_response: Fie, that youll say so! He plays o' the viol-de-gamboys,   and speaks three or four languages wordfor word without book,   and hath all the good gifts of nature.

translated_dialog: How dare you say so! He plays the violin, and speaks three or four languages word for word from memory. He has all of nature's good gifts.
og_response: He hath indeed, almost natural,   for besides that hes afool, hes a great quarreler,   and but that he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he hath in quarreling,   tis thought among the prudent he would quickly have the gift of a grave.

translated_dialog: He does indeed seem like a natural-born fooland besides being a fool, he's argumentative. If he didn't have the coward's gift of stepping away from a fight, they say he would've been long dead by now.
og_response: By this hand, they are scoundrels and substractors thatsay so of him. Who are they?

translated_dialog: By God, anyone who says that about him is a villain and a naysayer. Who said that?
og_response: They that add, moreover, hes drunk nightly in your company.

translated_dialog: They also say that he gets drunk with you every night.
og_response: With drinking healths to my niece. Ill drink to her aslong as there is a passage in my throat and drink in Illyria.   Hes a coward and a coistrel that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn o' th' toe like aparish top.   What, wench!    Castiliano vulgo    , for here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.

translated_dialog: We are only toasting my niece when we drink. I'll drink to her as long as there's a hole in my throat and alcohol in Illyria. Only cowards and scum wouldn't drink to my niece until their brains spin round like a top. What do you have to say to that! But hush, we must be polite. Here comes Sir Andrew Agueface himself.
og_response: Sir Toby Belch! How now, Sir Toby Belch!

translated_dialog: Sir Toby Belch! How are you, Sir Toby Belch?
og_response: Sweet Sir Andrew!

translated_dialog: Sweet Sir Andrew.
og_response: [To MARIA]  Bless you, fair shrew.

translated_dialog: [To MARIA] And hello to you, pretty wench.
og_response: And you too, sir.

translated_dialog: Hello to you, sir.
og_response: Accost, Sir Andrew, accost.

translated_dialog: Accost her, Sir Andrew, accost her.
og_response: Whats that?

translated_dialog: What's that?
og_response: My nieces chambermaid.

translated_dialog: This is my niece's chambermaid.
og_response: Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.

translated_dialog: Good Miss Accost-her, I look forward to knowing you better.
og_response: My name is Mary, sir.

translated_dialog: My name is Mary, sir.
og_response: Good Mistress Mary Accost

translated_dialog: Good Miss Mary Accost-her
og_response: You mistake, knight. Accost is front her, board her, woo her, assail her.

translated_dialog: You're mistaken, knight. "Accost her" isn't her nameI meant that you should face her, greet her, woo her, and conquer her.
og_response: By my troth, I would not undertake her in this company.Is that the meaning of accost?

translated_dialog: I say, I wouldn't do that in this company. Is that really what you meant by "accost her?"
og_response: Fare you well, gentlemen.  [she starts to exit]

translated_dialog: Goodbye, gentlemen. [She starts to exit]
og_response: An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst never draw sword again.

translated_dialog: If you let her leave like that, Sir Andrew, you don't deserve to ever draw your sword again.
og_response: An you part so, mistress, I would I might never draw sword again. Fair lady, do you think you have fools in hand?

translated_dialog: If you leave like this, miss, I swear I won't ever draw my sword again. Why are you leaving, fair ladydo you think you have fools on your hands here?
og_response: Sir, I have not you by the hand.

translated_dialog: Sir, I'm not holding your hand.
og_response: Marry, but you shall have, and heres my hand.  [he offers her his hand]

translated_dialog: Indeed, but you will be, and here's my hand. [He offers her his hand]
og_response: [taking his hand]   Now, sir, thought is free.   I pray you, bring your hand to the buttery-bar and let it drink.

translated_dialog: [Taking his hand] Now, sir, everyone has a right to their opinions. Please, take your hand to the dairy and let it drink.
og_response: Wherefore, sweetheart? Whats your metaphor?

translated_dialog: What do you mean, sweetheart? Is this a metaphor?
og_response: Its dry, sir.

translated_dialog: A dry one, sir.
og_response: Why, I think so. I am not such an ass, but I can keep my hand dry. But whats your jest?

translated_dialog: Well, I should hope so. I'm not such a fool that I can't keep my hand dry. But what's the joke?
og_response: A dry jest, sir.

translated_dialog: Just some dry humor, sir.
og_response: Are you full of them?

translated_dialog: Are you full of such jokes?
og_response: Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers' ends. Marry, now I let go your hand, I am barren.

translated_dialog: Yes, sir, I have a handful of them. Although now that I've let go of your hand, I've lost the biggest joke I had.
og_response: O knight, thou lackest a cup of canary. When did I see thee so put down?

translated_dialog: Oh knight, you need some wine. Have you ever been put down like that before?
og_response: Never in your life, I think, unless you see canary putme down.   Methinks sometimes I have no more wit than a Christian or an ordinary man has.   But I am a great eaterof beef, and I believe that does harm to my wit.

translated_dialog: Never, I think, except when I've been put down by too much wine. Sometimes I think I'm no smarter than a humble, ordinary man. But I eat a lot of beef, and maybe that hurts my intelligence.
og_response: No question.

translated_dialog: There's no question about that.
og_response: An I thought that, Id forswear it. Ill ride home tomorrow,Sir Toby.

translated_dialog: If I really thought that, I'd give up beef altogether. I think I'll ride home tomorrow, Sir Toby.
og_response: Pourquoi,  my dear knight?

translated_dialog: Pourquoi, my dear knight?
og_response: What is pourquoi? Do, or not do?   I would I had bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing, and bear-baiting. O, had I but followed the arts!

translated_dialog: What does "pourquoi" mean? Does it mean to do or not do? I wish I had spent more time learning languages instead of fencing, dancing, and bear-baiting. Oh, if I'd only studied more!
og_response: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.

translated_dialog: Then you would have an excellent head of hair.
og_response: Why, would that have mended my hair?

translated_dialog: Why, would that have improved my hair?
og_response: Past question, for thou seest it will not curl by nature.

translated_dialog: Certainly, for you can see that it won't curl naturally.
og_response: But it becomes me well enough, does t not?

translated_dialog: But my hair still suits me well enough, doesn't it?
og_response: Excellent. It hangs like flax on a distaff.   And I hopeto see a housewife take thee between her legs and spin it off.

translated_dialog: It looks excellent. It hangs like flax waiting to be spun. And I hope to see some hussy take it between her legs and spin it off with a venereal disease.
og_response: Faith, Ill home tomorrow, Sir Toby. Your niece will not be seen.   Or if she be, its four to one shell none of me.   The count himself here hard by woos her.

translated_dialog: Truly, I'm going home tomorrow, Sir Toby. Your niece refuses to see anyone. Even if she did see me, chances are she'd reject me. The duke himself is courting her nearby.
og_response: Shell none o' the count.   Shell not match above her degree, neither in estate, years, nor wit. I have heard her swear t   . Tut, theres life in t, man.

translated_dialog: She'll reject the duke. She won't marry anyone who's above her social rank, her wealth, her age, or her intelligenceI've heard her swear this. So cheer up, you're still in the running, man.
og_response: Ill stay a month longer.   I am a fellow o' th' strangest mind i' th' world. I delight in masques and revels sometimes altogether.

translated_dialog: I'll stay a month longer then. I must be the strangest fellow on earth. Sometimes my greatest pleasures are masquerades, plays, and dancing.
og_response: Art thou good at these kickshawses, knight?

translated_dialog: Are you good at such trifles, knight?
og_response: As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be, under the degree of my betters.   And yet I will not compare with anold man.

translated_dialog: As good as any man in Illyria, as long as he isn't better than I am. And yet I'm not as good as an experienced dancer.
og_response: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?

translated_dialog: How good are you at the fast dances, knight?
og_response: Faith, I can cut a caper.

translated_dialog: Well, I can cut a caper.
og_response: And I can cut the mutton to t.

translated_dialog: And I can cut the meat to go with your capers.
og_response: And I think I have the back-trick simply as strong as any man in Illyria.

translated_dialog: And I think I can do that tricky backward step as well as any man in Illyria.
og_response: Wherefore are these things hid? Wherefore have these gifts a curtain before 'em? Are they like to take dust, like Mistress Malls picture?   Why dost thou not go to church in a galliard and come home in a coranto?   My verywalk should be a jig. I would not so much as make waterbut in a sink-a-pace.   What dost thou mean? Is it a world to hide virtues in?   I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy leg, it was formed under the star ofa galliard.

translated_dialog: Why do you keep these things hidden? Why do you keep your gifts behind a curtain? Are you afraid they'll get dusty, like some woman's portrait? Why don't you show off your skill by going to church dancing a galliard and coming home dancing a coranto? If I were you, even my walk would be a dance. I wouldn't even pee unless I was dancing at the same time. What do you mean by this? Is this a world where we should hide our virtues? I could always tell from your excellent legs that you were born under a dancing star.
og_response: Ay, tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a dun-colored stock. Shall we set about some revels?

translated_dialog: Yes, my legs are strong, and they don't look bad in brown stockings. Should we have a little dance?
og_response: What shall we do else? Were we not born under Taurus?

translated_dialog: What else are we going to do? Weren't we born under the sign of Taurus?
og_response: Taurus! Thats sides and heart.

translated_dialog: Taurus! But that governs the torso and the heart.
og_response: No, sir, it is legs and thighs. Let me see the caper.  [SIRANDREW dances]  Ha, higher! Ha, ha, excellent!

translated_dialog: If the duke keeps favoring you like this, Cesario, you're likely to get promoted very high. He's only known you for three days, and already he's treating you like a friend.
og_response: You either fear his humor or my negligence, that you call in question the continuance of his love.   Is he inconstant, sir, in his favors?

translated_dialog: You must be afraid of his moodiness or my faults, if you think there's any chance that he'll stop liking me. Is he usually fickle in his moods and favors?
og_response: No, believe me.

translated_dialog: No, believe me.
og_response: I thank you. Here comes the count.

translated_dialog: I thank you for telling me. Here comes the duke.
og_response: Who saw Cesario, ho?

translated_dialog: Hey, has anyone seen Cesario?
og_response: On your attendance, my lord, here.

translated_dialog: I'm here, my lord, at your service.
og_response: [To VIOLA and attendants]    Stand you a while aloof.   [To VIOLA]   Cesario,    Thou knowst no less but all. I have unclasped    To thee the book even of my secret soul.    Therefore, good youth, address thy gait unto her;    Be not denied access, stand at her doors,    And tell them there thy fixed foot shall grow    Till thou have audience.

translated_dialog: [To attendants] Give us some privacy for a while. [To VIOLA] Cesario, you know everything about me. I have opened the book of my most secret soul to you. Therefore, good youth, direct your steps to Olivia's house. Don't let them deny you accessstand outside her door and tell them that you'll plant roots there until they let you see her.
og_response: Sure, my noble lord,    If she be so abandoned to her sorrow    As it is spoke   , she never will admit me.

translated_dialog: But my noble lord, if she is really as brokenhearted as they say, she is sure to deny me an audience.
og_response: Be clamorous, and leap all civil bounds,    Rather than make unprofited return.

translated_dialog: Be loud and obnoxious, and go beyond the limits of decency and civility if you have tojust don't come back without having spoken to her.
og_response: Say I do speak with her, my lord, what then?

translated_dialog: And if I do get to speak to her, my lord, what do I do then?
og_response: O, then unfold the passion of my love,    Surprise her with discourse of my dear faith:    It shall become thee well to act my woes;    She will attend it better in thy youth    Than in a nuncios of more grave aspect.

translated_dialog: Oh, then describe the passion of my love for her. Ambush her with descriptions of my faithfulness. It will be best if you act out my feelingsshe'll pay closer attention to you, as a young man, than to an older, more serious messenger.
og_response: I think not so, my lord.

translated_dialog: I don't think so, my lord.
og_response: Dear lad, believe it.    For they shall yet belie thy happy years    That say thou art a man.   Dianas lip    Is not more smooth and rubious. Thy small pipe    Is as the maidens organ, shrill and sound,    And all is semblative a womans part.    I know thy constellation is right apt    For this affair.   [To CURIO and attendants]    Some four or five attend him.    All, if you will, for I myself am best    When least in company.   [To VIOLA]   Prosper well in this,    And thou shalt live as freely as thy lord,    To call his fortunes thine.

translated_dialog: Dear boy, believe me. Anyone who says that you're a man is denying you the happy years of your youth. Your lips are as smooth and ruby-red as the goddess Diana's. Your small voice is like a girl's, high and clear, and the rest of you is feminine as well. I know you have been predestined to do this job. [To CURIO and attendants] Four or five of you go with him. All of you can go if you want to, for I feel my best when I'm away from people. [To VIOLA] If you succeed in this you will live as well as I do, and share in all my fortune.
og_response: Ill do my best    To woo your lady   [aside]   Yet, a barful strife    Whoe'er I woo, myself would be his wife.

translated_dialog: No, either tell me where you've been, or I won't say a word in your defense. My lady Olivia will have you hanged for being absent.
og_response: Let her hang me. He that is well hanged in this world needs to fear no colors.

translated_dialog: Let her hang me then. A well-hanged (and well-hung) man doesn't need to be afraid of anything he sees.
og_response: Make that good.

translated_dialog: Explainand clean up your language.
og_response: He shall see none to fear.

translated_dialog: He'll be dead, and so he won't see anything to be afraid of.
og_response: A good lenten answer. I can tell thee where that sayingwas born, of I fear no colors.

translated_dialog: That's a meager answer. And I can tell you where you got that saying about not being afraid of anything.
og_response: Where, good Mistress Mary?

translated_dialog: Where, good Mistress Mary?
og_response: In the wars. And that may you be bold to say in your foolery.

translated_dialog: From soldiers at war. And it's bold of you to talk like a soldier, when you're only a fool.
og_response: Well, God give them wisdom that have it. And those thatare fools, let them use their talents.

translated_dialog: Well, let God give wisdom to those who have it. Everyone has their talents, and for those of us who are fools, let us use our gifts.
og_response: Yet you will be hanged for being so long absent.   Or tobe turned away, is not that as good as a hanging to you?

translated_dialog: But you'll still be hanged for being gone so long. Or at least fired and kicked out, and wouldn't that be just as bad for you?
og_response: Many a good hanging prevents a bad marriage,   and, for turning away, let summer bear it out.

translated_dialog: Sometimes getting hanged saves a man from getting into a bad marriage, and as for getting kicked out, it's summer, so being homeless won't be so bad.
og_response: You are resolute, then?

translated_dialog: You are firm in your resolve, then?
og_response: Not so, neither, but I am resolved on two points.

translated_dialog: No, but I am resolved on two points.
og_response: That if one break, the other will hold.   Or, if both break, your gaskins fall.

translated_dialog: Yesthe two points where your suspenders are buttoned on. If one breaks, the other will hold. But if both break, your pants will fall.
og_response: Apt, in good faith, very apt. Well, go thy way.   If Sir Toby would leave drinking, thou wert as witty a piece ofEves flesh as any in Illyria.

translated_dialog: Very clever, really, very clever. Well, go along now. If only Sir Toby would stop drinking, you'd be a woman who was as funny as any person in Illyria.
og_response: Peace, you rogue, no more o' that. Here comes my lady.Make your excuse wisely, you were best.

translated_dialog: Quiet, you villain, no more of that. Here comes my lady. It would be best for you if you came up with a good excuse for being gone so long.
og_response: [aside]   Wit, an t be thy will, put me into good fooling!   Those wits, that think they have thee, do very oft prove fools.   And I, that am sure I lack thee, may pass for a wise man. For what says Quinapalus?   Better awitty fool, than a foolish wit.

translated_dialog: [To himself] Come on, wit, give me something good to say now! Those people who think they're witty often prove to be fools. And I'm sure that I'm not witty, so I might pass for a wise man. For what did the philosopher Quinapalus say? "Better a witty fool, than a foolish wit."
og_response: God bless thee, lady!

translated_dialog: God's greetings to you, my lady!
og_response: Take the fool away.

translated_dialog: Take the fool away.
og_response: Do you not hear, fellows? Take away the lady.

translated_dialog: Didn't you hear her, fellows? Take the lady away.

translated_dialog: Foolishness, sir, wanders about the earth like the sun. It's everywhere. I'd be sorry if your master was less acquainted with foolishness than my mistress is. I think I saw you there, you wise man.
og_response: Nay, an thou pass upon me, Ill no more with thee. Hold, theres expenses for thee.

translated_dialog: If you're just going to make fun of me, I want nothing to do with it. But wait, here's a coin for you.
og_response: Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send thee a beard!

translated_dialog: May God, in his next shipment of hair, send you a beard!
og_response: By my troth, Ill tell thee, I am almost sick for one,  (aside]  though I would not have it grow on my chin.  [To fool]  Is thy lady within?

translated_dialog: Honestly, I'm telling you, I'm dying for one, [To herself] though I don't want it on my own chinI'm dying for a certain man with a beard.
og_response: Would not a pair of these have bred, sir?

translated_dialog: If I had a pair of these coins, sir, do you think they'd have children?
og_response: Yes, being kept together and put to use.

translated_dialog: Yes, if they were kept together and invested.
og_response: I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia, sir, to bring aCressida to this Troilus.

translated_dialog: I'd like to play the pimp, sir, and bring these two lovers together.
og_response: [giving him money]  I understand you, sir. 'Tis well begged.

translated_dialog: [Giving him money] I understand you sir. You're pretty good at begging.
og_response: The matter, I hope, is not great, sir, begging but a beggar. Cressida was a beggar.   My lady is within, sir. Iwill construe to them whence you come.   Who you are and what you would are out of my welkin, I might say element, but the word is overworn.

translated_dialog: It's no problem for me, sir, as I'm only begging on a beggar's behalf. The famous lover Cressida became a beggar in her old age, they say. My lady is inside, sir. I'll explain where you come from, but who you are and what you want are beyond my knowledge. I'd say I'm "not in my element," but those words are overused.
og_response: This fellow is wise enough to play the fool,    And to do that well craves a kind of wit.    He must observe their mood on whom he jests,    The quality of persons, and the time,    And, like the haggard, check at every feather    That comes before his eye.   This is a practise    As full of labor as a wise mans art,    For folly that he wisely shows is fit.    But wise men, folly-fall'n, quite taint their wit.

translated_dialog: This fellow is wise enough to play the fool, and to do that well you have to be clever. He has to pay attention to the mood and status of the person he's mocking, the time, and must also pursue every target he sees. This is a skill that requires just as much work as any wise man's job, for he plays the fool very wisely. Wise men, on the other hand, ruin their reputation for intelligence when they try to play the fool.
og_response: Save you, gentleman.

translated_dialog: God bless you, sir.
og_response: And you, sir.

translated_dialog: And you, sir.
og_response: Dieu vous garde, monsieur.

translated_dialog: [Speaking in French] May God protect you, sir.
og_response: Et vous aussi. Votre serviteur!

translated_dialog: [Speaking in French] And you also. At your service!
og_response: I hope, sir, you are, and I am yours.

translated_dialog: I hope so, sir, and I am at your service too.
og_response: Will you encounter the house? My niece is desirous you should enter, if your trade be to her.

translated_dialog: Will you come in the house? My niece wants you to, if your business is with her.
og_response: I am bound to your niece, sir. I mean, she is the list of my voyage.

translated_dialog: I'm bound for your niece, sir. I mean, she's the destination of my voyage.
og_response: Taste your legs, sir. Put them to motion.

translated_dialog: Try your legs then sir, and put them in motion.
og_response: My legs do better understand me, sir, than I understandwhat you mean by bidding me taste my legs.

translated_dialog: My legs stand under me better than I understand you, and what you mean by "try your legs."
og_response: I mean, to go, sir, to enter.

translated_dialog: I mean to enter the house, sir.
og_response: I will answer you with gait and entrance. But we are prevented.

translated_dialog: I'll answer you by walking in. But we've been anticipated.
og_response: Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens rain odors on you!

translated_dialog: Most excellent accomplished lady, may the heavens rain odors upon you!
og_response: (  aside  ) That youths a rare courtier. Rain odors. Well.

translated_dialog: [To himself] That youth's a classy fellow. "Rain odors." Nice.
og_response: My matter hath no voice, lady, but to your own most pregnant and vouchsafed ear.

translated_dialog: My message can't be told to anyone, my lady. It's only for your own willing and receptive ears.
og_response: [aside]  Odors, pregnant, and vouchsafed. Ill get'em all three all ready.

translated_dialog: [To himself) "Odors," "willing," and "receptive." I'll have to remember those.
og_response: Let the garden door be shut, and leave me to my hearing.

translated_dialog: Close the garden door and let me be alone to hear this message.
og_response: Give me your hand, sir.

translated_dialog: Give me your hand, sir.
og_response: My duty, madam, and most humble service.

translated_dialog: I offer you my obedience, madam, and my most humble service.
og_response: What is your name?

translated_dialog: What is your name?
og_response: Cesario is your servants name, fair princess.

translated_dialog: Cesario is your servant's name, fair princess.
og_response: My servant, sir! 'Twas never merry world    Since lowly feigning was calld compliment.    Youre servant to the Count Orsino, youth.

translated_dialog: My servant, sir! The world has gone downhill since false humility started passing for a compliment. You're Duke Orsino's servant, youth, not mine.
og_response: And he is yours, and his must needs be yours:Your servants servant is your servant, madam.

translated_dialog: But he is your servant, so all that he has is yours too. Your servant's servant is your servant, madam.
og_response: For him, I think not on him. For his thoughts,Would they were blanks, rather than filld with me.

translated_dialog: As for him, I don't think about him. And as for his thoughts, I wish that they were blank pages instead of filled with pictures of me.
og_response: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughtsOn his behalf.

translated_dialog: Madam, I've come on his behalf to improve your feelings towards him.
og_response: O, by your leave, I pray you,    I bade you never speak again of him.    But, would you undertake another suit,    I had rather hear you to solicit that    Than music from the spheres.

translated_dialog: Oh, please, I beg you, I asked you never speak of him again. But if you would tell me that another man loves me instead, I would rather hear that than angels singing.
og_response: Dear lady

translated_dialog: Dear lady
og_response: Give me leave, beseech you. I did send,    After the last enchantment you did here,    A ring in chase of you.   So did I abuse    Myself, my servant, and, I fear me, you:    Under your hard construction must I sit,    To force that on you, in a shameful cunning    Which you knew none of yours.   What might you think?    Have you not set mine honor at the stake,    And baited it with all the unmuzzled thoughts    That tyrannous heart can think?   To one of your receiving    Enough is shown.   A cypress, not a bosom,    Hides my heart. So, let me hear you speak.

translated_dialog: Please, let me speak. After the magic spell you cast on me last time you were here, I sent that ring to you. With that trick I degraded myself, my servant, and you, I'm afraid. I must then accept your judgment of this act, which you probably condemnfor I forced that ring on you through shameful trickery, and without your consent. What must you think of me? Haven't you tied my honor to a stake like a bear, and let the hounds of your anger attack it? But I've shown my situation clearly enough for someone of your intelligence to understand. My heart's on my sleeveI can't hide my passion. So let me hear you speak.
og_response: I pity you.

translated_dialog: I pity you.
og_response: Thats a degree to love.

translated_dialog: That's a step towards love.
og_response: No, not a grize. For tis a vulgar proofThat very oft we pity enemies.

translated_dialog: No, not a step. It's a common experience that we often pity our enemies.
og_response: Why then methinks tis time to smile again.    O world, how apt the poor are to be proud!    If one should be a prey, how much the better    To fall before the lion than the wolf!

translated_dialog: Then I think it's time for me to smile again. Oh, how easy it is for the poor to be proud of something they don't have! But if I must be defeated, then better to be defeated by a noble enemy than a lowly one.
og_response: The clock upbraids me with the waste of time.    Be not afraid, good youth, I will not have you.    And yet when wit and youth is come to harvest,    Your wife is like to reap a proper man.    There lies your way, due west.

translated_dialog: See, the clock scolds me for wasting time. Don't worry, youth, I won't keep pursuing you. And when you're older and wiser, your future wife will have a fine handsome husband. There's your way back home, due west.
og_response: Then westward ho!Grace and good disposition attend your ladyship!Youll nothing, madam, to my lord by me?

translated_dialog: Then I'm off to the west! I wish you the best of fortune. You don't have a message for the duke?
og_response: Stay, I prithee, tell me what thou thinkest of me.

translated_dialog: Stay, please, and tell me what you really think of me.
og_response: That you do think you are not what you are.

translated_dialog: I think that you're not who you think you are.
og_response: If I think so, I think the same of you.

translated_dialog: If that's true, then I think the same thing of you.
og_response: Then think you right: I am not what I am.

translated_dialog: Then you're correct. I am not what I seem to be.
og_response: I would you were as I would have you be!

translated_dialog: I wish you were what I want you to be!
og_response: Would it be better, madam, than I am? I wish it might, for now I am your fool.

translated_dialog: Would that be better, madam, than me being what I am? I wish that it would, for right now I'm a fool.
og_response: (aside]   Oh, what a deal of scorn looks beautiful    In the contempt and anger of his lip!    A murderous guilt shows not itself more soon    Than love that would seem hid. Loves night is noon.    [To   VIOLA]   Cesario, by the roses of the spring,    By maidhood, honor, truth, and everything,    I love thee so,   that, maugre all thy pride,    Nor wit nor reason can my passion hide.    Do not extort thy reasons from this clause,    For that I woo, thou therefore hast no cause,    But rather reason thus with reason fetter.    Love sought is good, but given unsought better.

translated_dialog: [To herself] Oh, look how beautiful he is even in his anger and contempt! A murderer's guilt is easier to hide than feelings of love. Midday is like nighttime for lovethat's how brightly passion shines. [To VIOLA] Cesario, I swear by the roses of spring, by virginity, by honor, by truth, and by everything, that I love you. I love you so much that neither my wit nor my reason can hide my passion, despite your pride. Don't draw the wrong conclusions from this, thoughjust because I'm wooing you doesn't mean you shouldn't woo me. Use your better logic and see that love asked for is good, but love freely given is better.
og_response: By innocence I swear, and by my youth    I have one heart, one bosom, and one truth,    And that no woman has, nor never none    Shall mistress be of it, save I alone.    And so adieu, good madam. Nevermore    Will I my masters tears to you deplore.

translated_dialog: And I swear by innocence and by my own youth that I have only one heart and one love to give, and no woman has ever ruled them, and never willexcept for myself. And so I'll say farewell, good madam. I'll never again try to make you pity my master's passion.
og_response: Yet come again, for thou perhaps mayst move That heart, which now abhors, to like his love.

translated_dialog: No, really, I won't stay a moment longer.
og_response: Thy reason, dear venom, give thy reason.

translated_dialog: What's your reason for leaving, my bitter friend?
og_response: You must needs yield your reason, Sir Andrew.

translated_dialog: Yes, you must tell us your reason, Sir Andrew.
og_response: Marry, I saw your niece do more favors to the Counts servingman than ever she bestowed upon me. I sawt i'theorchard.

translated_dialog: Well, I saw your niece Olivia treating the Duke's messenger better than she has ever treated me. I saw it in the garden.
og_response: Did she see thee the while, old boy? Tell me that.

translated_dialog: Did she see you at the time though, old boy? Tell me that.
og_response: As plain as I see you now.

translated_dialog: Yes, she saw me as plainly as I see you now.
og_response: This was a great argument of love in her toward you.

translated_dialog: Then that was proof that she loves you.
og_response: 'Slight, will you make an ass o' me?

translated_dialog: What, are trying to make a fool of me?
og_response: I will prove it legitimate, sir, upon the oaths of judgment and reason.

translated_dialog: I'll prove it to be true, sir, with judgment and logic.
og_response: And they have been grand-jurymen since before Noah was a sailor.

translated_dialog: And judgment and logic have been wise jury members since the time of Noah's ark.
og_response: She did show favor to the youth in your sight only to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valor, to put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver.   You should then have accosted her, and with some excellent jests, fire-new from the mint, you should have banged the youth into dumbness.   This was looked for at your hand, and this was balked.   The double gilt of this opportunity you let time wash off, and you are now sailed into the north of my ladys opinion, where you will hang like an icicle on a Dutchmans beard,   unless you do redeem it by some laudable attempt either of valor or policy.

translated_dialog: She treated the youth so well while you were watching to exasperate and anger you, to wake up your meekly sleeping boldness, to fire up your passions. You should have approached her that minute, whipped out some excellent jokes you invented right there on the spot, and humiliated the youth into silence. That was the opening she gave you, but you missed it. This was a golden opportunity for you, but you let it slip away, and now you've sailed out of the warmth of my lady's good opinion. You'll stay there like an icicle in a sailor's beard unless you can redeem yourself to her through some noble act of bravery or politics.
og_response: An t be any way, it must be with valor, for policy I hate. I had as lief be a Brownist as a politician.

translated_dialog: If I have to do something, it must be something brave, for I hate politics. I'd rather be a heretic than a politician.
og_response: Why, then, build me thy fortunes upon the basis of valor. Challenge me the counts youth to fight with him.   Hurt him in eleven places. My niece shall take note of it,   and assure thyself, there is no love-broker in the world can more prevail in mans commendation with woman than report of valor.

translated_dialog: Well then, improve your fortunes through your bravery. Challenge the duke's young servant to a fight. Hurt him in eleven places. My niece will notice this, and let me assure you, no matchmaker in the world can win you a woman's love like a reputation for bravery can.
og_response: There is no way but this, Sir Andrew.

translated_dialog: This is the only way, Sir Andrew.
og_response: Will either of you bear me a challenge to him?

translated_dialog: Will either of you deliver the message of my challenge to him?
og_response: Go, write it in a martial hand. Be curst and brief. Itis no matter how witty, so it be eloquent and full of invention.   Taunt him with the license of ink.   If thou thou-est him some thrice, it shall not be amiss; and as many lies as will lie in thy sheet of paper, althoughthe sheet were big enough for the bed of Ware in England, set 'em down.   Go, about it. Let there be gall enough in thy ink, though thou write with a goose-pen, no matter. About it.

translated_dialog: Go and write it down, in fierce handwriting. Be rude and brief. It doesn't need to be witty, as long as it's eloquent and original. Taunt him with all the possibilities of writing. Refer to him familiarly three times at least, which will insult his pride as a nobleman. As many lies as you can fit on a piece of papereven if the paper's as big as a royal bedwrite 'em all down. Go, get started now. Even if you're using an ordinary pen, you can still fill it with bitter, venomous ink. Now go ahead.
og_response: Where shall I find you?

translated_dialog: Where will I find you when I'm done?
og_response: Well call thee at the cubiculo. Go.

translated_dialog: We'll meet you in the little room. Now go.
og_response: This is a dear manikin to you, Sir Toby.

translated_dialog: This knight is a beloved puppet to you, Sir Toby.
og_response: I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand strong,or so.

translated_dialog: And I've been a beloved expense to him, as he's spent two thousand or so of his ducats on me.
og_response: We shall have a rare letter from him: but youll not deliver t?

translated_dialog: His letter's sure to be a work of art. But you won't deliver it, will you?
og_response: Never trust me, then. And by all means stir on the youth to an answer. I think oxen and wainropes cannot hale them together.   For Andrew, if he were opened and you find so much blood in his liver as will clog the foot of a flea, Ill eat the rest of the anatomy.

translated_dialog: Never trust me again if I don't. And by all means encourage the youth to answer the knight's challenge. An oxcart couldn't haul them close enough together to fight. As for Andrew, if you dissected him and found enough red blood in his liver for even a flea to notice, I'd eat the rest of his body. He's a coward through and through.
og_response: And his opposite, the youth, bears in his visage no great presage of cruelty.

translated_dialog: And his opponent, the youth, doesn't seem to have much aggression in his face either.
og_response: Look where the youngest wren of nine comes.

translated_dialog: Look, here comes the smallest bird of all.
og_response: If you desire the spleen, and will laugh yourself into stitches, follow me.   Yond gull Malvolio is turned heathen, a very renegado. For there is no Christian thatmeans to be saved by believing rightly can ever believesuch impossible passages of grossness.   Hes in yellow stockings.

translated_dialog: If you want to have a laughing fit, and really laugh until you split your sides, then follow me. That gullible Malvolio must have renounced Christianity, for no Christian who intends to go to heaven by his faith could ever believe the absurd, exaggerated things like we put in that letter. He's wearing yellow stockings.
og_response: And cross-gartered?

translated_dialog: With crossed laces?
og_response: Most villanously, like a pedant that keeps a school i' the church.   I have dogged him, like his murderer. He does obey every point of the letter that I dropped to betray him.   He does smile his face into more lines than is in the new map with the augmentation of the Indies.    You have not seen such a thing as tis. I can hardly forbear hurling things at him.   I know my lady will strike him. If she do, hell smile and take t for a great favor.

translated_dialog: Yes, and they look awfullike an unfashionable village schoolteacher. I've been stalking him like a murderer, and he's followed every instruction I gave in that letter I dropped. He smiles so much that his face has more lines in it than a map of the Indies. You've never seen anything like this. I can hardly keep from throwing things at him. I know my lady will get so annoyed she'll hit him eventually, and when she does, he'll just smile and imagine that she's flattering him.
og_response: Come, bring us, bring us where he is.

translated_dialog: I didn't want to trouble you, but you seem to take pleasure in enduring suffering, so I won't scold you about it anymore.
og_response: I could not stay behind you. My desire,    More sharp than filèd steel, did spur me forth.    And not all love to see you, though so much    As might have drawn one to a longer voyage,    But jealousy what might befall your travel,    Being skilless in these parts, which to a stranger,    Unguided and unfriended, often prove    Rough and unhospitable.   My willing love,    The rather by these arguments of fear,    Set forth in your pursuit.

translated_dialog: I couldn't stay behind. My desire to go was sharper than a knife, and it spurred me onward. It wasn't just love for you, though that much might have inspired a man to go on an even longer voyage. I was also worried about what might happen to you in your travels, since you don't know this area, and it can be rough and inhospitable to a stranger without a guide or friend. My willing love for you, combined with these fears for your safety, drove me to follow you.
og_response: My kind Antonio,    I can no other answer make but thanks,    And thanks, and ever thanks.   And oft good turns    Are shuffled off with such uncurrent pay.    But were my worth as is my conscience, firm,    You should find better dealing.   Whats to do?    Shall we go see the relics of this town?

translated_dialog: My kind Antonio, the only answer I can give you is thanks, and thanks, and infinite thanks. Often such good deeds are only rewarded with cheap words, but if I had any wealth I would strengthen my gratitude with money. Now what should we do? Should we go see the monuments of this town?
og_response: Tomorrow, sir. Best first go see your lodging.

translated_dialog: We'll do that tomorrow, sir. First we should find a place for you to stay.
og_response: I am not weary, and tis long to night:    I pray you, let us satisfy our eyes    With the memorials and the things of fame    That do renown this city.

translated_dialog: I'm not weary, and night is a long way away. Please, let's go satisfy our eyes with the sight of the memorials and statues that make this city famous.
og_response: Would youd pardon me;    I do not without danger walk these streets:    Once in a sea-fight 'gainst the Count his galleys    I did some service, of such note indeed,    That were I ta'en here it would scarce be answered.

translated_dialog: I hope you'll pardon me: I can't walk these streets without being in danger. Once in a battle at sea I served on the side fighting against Duke Orsino's ships, and I distinguished myself enough that I might be recognized. If I were arrested here, they'd make me answer for my deeds.
og_response: Belike you slew great number of his people?

translated_dialog: Then you must have killed many of his men?
og_response: The offence is not of such a bloody nature;    Albeit the quality of the time and quarrel    Might well have given us bloody argument.    It might have since been answered in repaying    What we took from them, which, for traffics sake,    Most of our city did.   Only myself stood out;    For which, if I be lapsèd in this place,    I shall pay dear.

translated_dialog: My deeds weren't so bloody as that, though we had just cause to shed some blood over that quarrel. We could have since resolved the matter by paying reparations for the damage we did to them in battle, for the sake of maintaining our trade relations. Most of our city did. I was the only one who refused to pay anything. That's why I'll pay dearly if I should be cap here.
og_response: Do not then walk too open.

translated_dialog: Then don't walk around too conspicuously.
og_response: It doth not fit me. Hold, sir, heres my purse.    [giving him money]    In the south suburbs, at the Elephant,    Is best to lodge.   I will bespeak our diet,    Whiles you beguile the time and feed your knowledge    With viewing of the town. There shall you have me.

translated_dialog: It's not a good idea for me, certainly. Wait, sir, here's my purse. [Giving SEBASTIAN some money] The best place to stay is an inn called the Elephant. It's in the suburbs to the south. I'll order our meals while you spend your time pleasantly and educate yourself by exploring the town. You can find me back at the Elephant.
og_response: Why I your purse?

translated_dialog: Why should I take your purse, though?
og_response: Haply your eye shall light upon some toy    You have desire to purchase,   and your store,    I think, is not for idle markets, sir.

translated_dialog: Just if some trinket should catch your eye and you want to buy itI have the feeling that your store of money isn't large enough for useless purchases.
og_response: Ill be your purse-bearer and leave youFor an hour.

translated_dialog: I'll carry your purse then, and leave you for an hour.
og_response: To the Elephant.

translated_dialog: And meet me at the Elephant.
og_response: I do remember.

translated_dialog: [To herself] I've sent for him. He says he'll come. What food should I give him? What gifts? For it's better to buy something than beg for it or borrow itand it's the same with youth and love. But I'm speaking too loud. [To MARIA] Where's Malvolio? He is very serious and solemn, which is appropriate for someone in mourning like I am. Where is Malvolio?
og_response: Hes coming, madam; but in very strange manner. He is sure possessed, madam.

translated_dialog: He's coming, madam, but in a very strange manner. He seems crazy, madam.
og_response: Why, whats the matter? Does he rave?

translated_dialog: Why, what's the matter? Is he talking nonsense?
og_response: No, madam, he does nothing but smile. Your ladyship were best to have some guard about you if he come, for sure the man is tainted in s wits.

translated_dialog: No, madam, he does nothing but smile. It would be best if you had a guard nearby if he comes here, for the man is surely sick in his head.
og_response: Go call him hither.

translated_dialog: Go call him here.
og_response: I am as mad as he, If sad and merry madness equal be.

translated_dialog: I am as mad as he is, if sad madness and merry madness are equals.
og_response: How now, Malvolio?

translated_dialog: What's going on, Malvolio?
og_response: Sweet lady, ho, ho.

translated_dialog: Sweet lady, hello.
og_response: Smilest thou? I sent for thee upon a sad occasion.

translated_dialog: Are you smiling? I sent for you on a sad occasion.
og_response: Sad, lady! I could be sad. This does make some obstruction in the blood, this cross-gartering, but whatof that?   If it please the eye of one, it is with me as the very true sonnet is, Please one, and please all.

translated_dialog: Sad, my lady! I could be sad. These crossed laces do cut off the circulation in my legs a bit, but what of that? If a certain person likes them, then it's like that poem says: "Please one, and please all."
og_response: Why, how dost thou, man? What is the matter with thee?

translated_dialog: Why, what's going on, man? What is the matter with you?
og_response: Not black in my mind, though yellow in my legs.   It did come to his hands, and commands shall be executed. I think we do know the sweet Roman hand.

translated_dialog: My legs are yellow, but I don't feel blue. The letter came to me, and its commands must be obeyed. I think I recognized the fancy Italian handwriting.
og_response: Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?

translated_dialog: Don't you think you ought to go to bed, Malvolio?
og_response: To bed? Ay, sweetheart, and Ill come to thee.

translated_dialog: To bed? "Yes, sweetheart, I'll come to you."
og_response: God comfort thee! Why dost thou smile so, and kiss thyhand so oft?

translated_dialog: For God's sake! Why are you smiling like that, and kissing your hand so often?
og_response: How do you, Malvolio?

translated_dialog: Are you okay, Malvolio?
og_response: At your request! Yes, nightingales answer daws!

translated_dialog: You think I'll answer you? Noblemen don't answer servants!
og_response: Why appear you with this ridiculous boldness before my lady?

translated_dialog: Why are you acting with such ridiculous arrogance in front of my lady?
og_response: Be not afraid of greatness. 'Twas well writ.

translated_dialog: "Don't be afraid of my greatness." It was well written.
og_response: What meanest thou by that, Malvolio?

translated_dialog: What do you mean by that, Malvolio?
og_response: Some are born great

translated_dialog: "Some are born great"
og_response: Ha?

translated_dialog: What?
og_response: Some achieve greatness

translated_dialog: "Some achieve greatness"
og_response: What sayest thou?

translated_dialog: What did you say?
og_response: And some have greatness thrust upon them.

translated_dialog: "And some have greatness thrust upon them."
og_response: Heaven restore thee!

translated_dialog: May heaven restore your sanity!
og_response: Remember who commended thy yellow stockings

translated_dialog: "Remember who it was who complimented your yellow stockings"
og_response: Thy yellow stockings?

translated_dialog: Your yellow stockings?
og_response: And wished to see thee cross-gartered.
